Hummus is made from ingredients that, following Kashrut (Jewish dietary laws), can be combined with both meat and dairy meals.
Chickpea dishes have long been part of the cuisine of Jews who lived in the Middle East and Northern Africa.
British dictionaries give houmous or hoummos as alternatives.
The major British supermarkets use houmous.
One survey found that 41% of Britons had hummus in their fridge, twice as many as the rest of Europe.
A Waitrose spokesperson said hummus had become a grocery staple.
Nutritional content of hummus varies.
Nutritional content depends primarily on the relative proportions of chickpeas, tahini, and water.
